Graphical abstract This review introduced the recent development of the application of fullerenes in rechargeable batteries and summarized the current issues and future directions. The development of high-performance batteries is inseparable from the exploration of new materials. Among them, fullerene C60 as an allotrope of carbon has many unique properties that are beneficial for battery applications, including precise structure, controllable derivatization, good solubility, and rich redox chemistry. In this review, we summarize the recent progress of fullerene-based materials in the field of rechargeable batteries and the key issues that need to be solved in the future application of fullerene. We hope this review can provide guidance and stimulate research about the applications of fullerenes in the field of energy storage. Keywords Batteries Fullerene Carbon materials Energy storage 1 Introduction Energy demand is increasingly augmented with the development of the global economy, which urgently requires developing various rechargeable batteries to reduce the overuse of fossil fuels and mitigate environmental pollution and resource depletion [1–3]. As the most well-known rechargeable battery, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have undoubtedly brought great convenience to modern society in the past two decades, especially in the field of electric vehicles, grid-scale energy storage, and portable electronics [4–6]. Also, other types of batteries, such as lithium metal batteries (LMBs) with high theoretical energy density [7–9], and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with a competitive price advantage [10–12], have appeared successively and have the potential to apply to next-generation battery systems. Therefore, numerous studies have been devoted to developing new materials for high-performance batteries with prospects in practical applications [13–15]. Buckminsterfullerene (C60), first discovered in 1985, as an allotrope of carbon with an ideal spherical structure, is regarded as the most representative zero-dimensional carbon material [16,17]. A C60 molecule has an ideal cage structure with a unique π-conjugated system, which is composed of 60 sp2-hybridized carbon atoms, including 12 pentagons and 20 hexagons [18]. As the research of fullerene chemistry has deepened, the fullerene family has been further expanded, including various higher fullerenes [19–21], endohedral metallofullerenes [22–24], and a series of fullerene derivatives [25–27]. Meanwhile, more fullerene application fields have been developed, such as photovoltaics [28–30], catalysis [31–33], and biomedicine [34–36]. For battery applications, fullerene has received less attention than other carbon materials owing to their relatively high cost compared with one-dimensional carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and two-dimensional graphene [37–39]. However, various unique properties of fullerene bring tremendous potential in the field of rechargeable batteries. As shown in Fig. 1 , fullerene C60 has a precise structure with abundant unsaturated bonds that can be easily functionalized to produce various derivatives, which could effectively decrease the structural/componential heterogeneity issue that troubles many carbon materials [40–42]. Moreover, pristine fullerenes are highly soluble in many organic solvents (carbon disulfide, benzene, toluene, etc.), and the solubility in different solvents as carbonate, ether, and aqueous solutions can be further modified by appropriate derivatization [43–45]. Hence, fullerene can be applied to regulate the liquid phase reaction process in battery systems. Finally, fullerenes also show excellent electron-accepting ability, endowing them with rich redox chemistry during battery cycling [46–48]. In this review, we outline the recent state-of-the-art developments of fullerene-based materials (including pristine fullerene and its derivatives) in the field of batteries, including advanced LIBs, emerging LMBs, promising SIBs, and other rechargeable batteries. Meanwhile, we provide an outlook on pressing issues, potential challenges, and future directions of fullerene for battery applications. We hope this review can provide guidance for designing various fullerene-based materials for batteries and inspire further relevant research. 2 Lithium-ion batteries Most studies have used fullerene as an anode material for LIBs as it is an allotrope of carbon. For pristine C60, the typical Li storage mechanism is the intercalation of a lithium-ion (Li+) between C60 molecules to form LiXC60 [49]. Despite possessing rich redox activity and high conductivity, pure C60 cannot be used directly as an electrode material because the intercalation of Li+ into C60 can significantly affect its electronic structure, leading to a poor reversible capacity [50,51]. Therefore, obtaining a high-performance, fullerene-based electrode material requires further modifications, such as doping, hybridization, and derivatization [52,53]. For example, Zhu et al. [54] activated C60 with KOH at various temperatures in an NH3 atmosphere to prepare N-doped C60 samples. After high-temperature activation, pristine C60 molecules were converted into porous carbon doped with abundant pyrrolic and pyridinic N as along with defects (Fig. 2 a). Electrochemical tests showed that this N-doped C60 sample exhibited a high reversible capacity of 1900 mAh g−1 (100 mA g−1) and outstanding rate performance (600 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1) as a LIB anode. Similarly, the Yang group [55] synthesized a C60-embedded nitrogen-doped carbon material (C60@N-MPC) by direct carbonation of a C60-embedded zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (C60@ZIF-8) precursor (Fig. 2b). The C60@N-MPC as a LIB anode showed an improved reversible capacity of 1351 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and a good rate capacity of 403 mAh g−1 at 10 A g−1. However, during the preparation of such carbon materials doped with various elements, the high-temperature carbonization treatment also destroys the structure of the fullerene, so the prepared carbon material cannot inherit most of its properties. The corresponding mechanism of lithium storage in these modified fullerene-based materials is possibly similar to that in porous carbon materials, which tends to be surface adsorption more than lithium insertion [56]. Different from the above paths, Kang et al. [57] developed a novel conducting agent-free electrode made with pristine C60 and a hexabenzocoronene (cHBC) cocrystal composite (Fig. 2c). This C60/cHBC cocrystal anode presented not only good Li+ storage ability but also excellent electronic conductivity because this type of cocrystal structure could be regarded as an organic semiconducting material with well-defined p-n junctions. As a result, this conducting agent-free anode (C60/cHBC/binder with a mass ratio of 45: 45: 10) delivered a reversible capacity of 330 mAh g−1 (0.1 A g−1) and retained 80% reversible capacity after 600 cycles at a current density of 1 A g−1. Derivatization is another route to prepare fullerene-based anodes. Different functional groups can significantly alter the properties of fullerene. Wang et al. [58] systematically studied the Li+ storage abilities of fullerene with various functional groups. Series of fullerene derivatives were successfully synthesized and used as anode materials for LIBs, including pristine C60, neutral ester C60, negative carboxyl C60, and positive piperazine C60 (Fig. 3 a). Experiment results showed negative carboxyl C60 with the highest discharge capacity (861 mAh g−1) after 100 cycles at 0.1C, and neutral ester C60 with a discharge capacity of 404 mAh g−1 (Fig. 3b). In comparison, positive piperazine C60 disclosed the lowest discharge capacity of 83 mAh g−1, which was even inferior to pristine C60 (170 mAh g−1). The plausible rationale is that the carboxyl C60 with a rich electron-donating group can absorb more Li+ on the fullerene surface while the piperazine C60 with an abundant electron-withdrawing group is likely to repel partial Li+. This research guides the design of fullerene derivatives as anode materials. In addition, Joseph et al. [59] reported hydrogenated fullerenes (C60H x ) as anodes in LIBs and demonstrated that C60H18 could adsorb about 12Li per C60, with the highest storage capacity, up to 588 mAh g−1 after 600 cycles at a current density of 0.05 A g−1 (Fig. 3c). More recently, through a dehydration condensation reaction, Wang et al. [60] prepared a C60(OH)12/graphene oxide (GO) composite as an anode material (Fig. 3d). This anode composite retained an excellent charge capacity of 1596 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at a current density of 0.2 A g−1. However, like many other carbon materials, fullerene-based anode materials exhibit a low initial Coulombic efficiency (CE, generally below 60%). In addition, fullerene-based anode materials have a complicated synthesis process and high cost, which undoubtedly restrict the large-scale application of fullerene-based anode materials in LIBs. Thus, fullerene-based anode materials currently have no prominent superiority compared to commercial anode materials for LIBs in practical applications (graphite and Si/C). Apart from being used as anode materials, recent research shows that fullerene-based materials can play other roles in LIBs, such as coating and electrolyte additives. For example, through plasma-assisted thermal evaporation technology, the Lee group developed polymerized C60 as a protective coating layer on Si anodes [61–63], LiCoO2 (LCO) cathodes [64], and Sn alloy anodes [65,66]. Typically, polymerized C60-coated LCO [64] can significantly enhance interfacial stability and provide a rapid Li+ diffusion pathway, thereby showing improved capacity retention and superior CE within a high-voltage window (3–4.5 V, Fig. 4 a). In addition, the Lee group also employed polymerized C60 as a self-relaxant superelastic matrix coated on Sn nanoparticles [66] to obtain an ultra-stable alloy anode that showed a high discharge capacity of 858.46 mAh g−1 and high capacity retention of 97.18% after 5000 cycles at a current density of 1 A g−1 (Fig. 4b). However, it is difficult to use this polymerized C60 film on a large scale due to the complicated pretreatment progress. On the other hand, since fullerene-based materials are redox-active and soluble in various solvents, they can be designed as electrolyte additives to regulate an electrochemical reaction. More importantly, such additives are usually highly effective, resulting in a low dosage (generally below 1 wt%), which can alleviate the cost issue of fullerene-based materials. Recently, Kwak et al. [67] reported a novel anti-aging electrolyte additive using malonic acid-decorated fullerene (MA-C60, adding 1 wt%) for Li-rich cathodes. The MA-C60 can not only serve as superoxide dismutase activity to inhibit the solvent decomposition but also has excellent water scavenging capability to sustain a long-term, stable cathode electrolyte interface (Fig. 4c). A performance test showed that the Li-rich‖silicon-graphite composite full cell, using the modified electrolyte with MA-C60 exhibited improved capacity retention over 100 cycles with a high average CE of 99.5% (Fig. 4d). This work designed a functional additive by rationally exploiting the properties of fullerene, which opened up a new direction for the application of fullerene in LIBs. 3 Lithium metal batteries Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) are regarded as a promising next-generation battery system with potentially high energy density (>300 Wh kg−1), employing a lithium metal anode (LMA) that has a high theoretical capacity up to 3860 mAh g−1 and redox potential as low as − 3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode [68–70]. However, the inhomogeneous deposition of lithium and the unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) greatly shorten the cycle lifespan of LMBs, thus hindering their practical application [71–73]. Recent research shows that fullerene can play a special role in LMA protection. Li et al. [74] reported a metallic Li foil with a C60/Mg bilayer hybrid interphase prepared by vacuum evaporation deposition (Fig. 5 a). Benefiting from the synergistic effect of the bilayer film, this protected Li foil not only suppressed the growth of lithium dendrites to extend cycle life but also showed excellent air stability to meet practical processing requirements. Air stability tests showed that the protected Li foil retained good electrochemical activity even after 12 h exposition in air with a relative humidity of 30% (Fig. 5b). In this work, C60 was designed as a hydrophobic layer, representing a different property from the other reports of fullerene coatings [75,76]. In addition, the Xie group [77] developed a novel fullerene additive, nitro-C60, which showed a bifunctional effect in the LMA, including smoothing and protecting. The possible mechanism is that soluble nitro-C60 easily decomposed into NO2 − and insoluble C60 (Fig. 5c). Then, the NO2 − may have further formed the protective N-rich SEI with quick Li+ transport ability, and the insoluble C60 may have preferentially smoothed the uneven Li surface due to the electrostatic interactions. Full cells, including lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries and high voltage Li‖LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 (NCM622) batteries using the carbonate electrolyte with the addition of nitro-C60 (5 mM), showed a significantly improved cycling stability even under the practical conditions of high areal capacity, lean electrolytes, and limited Li excess. This work is the first report of using functional fullerene as an electrolyte additive in LMBs, shining a new light on the application of fullerene in rechargeable batteries. Nevertheless, the application of fullerenes in LMBs remains limited so far. In future exploration, fullerene may play a more important role in LMBs. 4 Sodium-ion batteries Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have the advantages of a rich-resource and low-cost, thus receiving widespread attention [78,79]. Developing high-performing sodium storage anode material is a crucial issue for SIB studies [80]. Pontiroli et al. [81] explored the potential application of pure C60 and a hydrogenated derivative (C60H x ) for SIB anodes. Similar to the previous reports of fullerene-based LIB anodes, their studies showed that pure C60 could not be used directly as an electrode material for SIBs, because it displayed a strong irreversible Na-inserted behavior, forming Na x C60 composites (Fig. 6 a). The C60H x electrode displayed significantly better reversibility due to its increased steric hindrance. Their group also found [82] that the mixture of C60/C70 as a SIB anode improved the reversibility of Na+ storage, and the initial discharge capacity went up to 320 mAh g−1. In addition, He et al. [83] prepared Na-doped C70 fullerene (Na-C70)/N-doped graphene (N-GN)/Fe-based nanocomposites (Na-C70/N-GN/FBNCs) as SIB anode materials, which achieved the highest discharge capacity, up to 1898 mAh g−1 and retained a reversible capacity of 238 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at a current density of 1 A g−1 (Fig. 6b). Their group also reported [84] a novel C60/Na4FeO3/high-energy Li3V2(PO4)3/soft carbon (C60/NFO/HE-LVP/SC) hybrid electrode as a battery-supercapacitor hybrid devices (BSHs). The introduction of C60 not only brought high conductivity and provided some degree of crystallinity, but also delivered an extra pseudo-capacitance (Fig. 6c). The rate test showed that this hybrid electrode exhibited a discharge capacity of 77.3 mAh g−1 at 10C, indicating its ultrafast kinetics (Fig. 6d). Compared with LIBs, the research on fullerene as an anode material for SIBs needs to be further expanded. Also, many essential battery parameters and tests need to be taken into full consideration in future research, such as initial CE and full cell tests. 5 Other battery systems In addition to the extensively studied battery systems mentioned above, fullerenes can also be used in other battery systems. For instance, C60 can interact with Mg-ion (Mg2+) to form MgxC60 (Fig. 7 a) and has potential as an electrode material for Mg batteries (MBs) [85,86]. Ling et al. [87] first reported the application of a C60 cathode in a rechargeable magnesium battery, as shown in Fig. 7b. At a current density of 19 μA cm−2, the Mg-C60 battery showed two discharge plateaus at 1.4 V and 1.1 V with a capacity of 37 mAh g−1 and 13 mAh g−1, respectively, which could be attributed to C60/C60 − and C60 −/C60 2− according to the result of the corresponding cyclic voltammogram (CV) curve. This work opens a new horizon for the application of fullerene and the development of MBs. Mustarelli et al. [88] studied poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO)-Li4C60 as a mixed conductor in solid-state batteries (SSBs), which showed a predominant Li+ conductivity (t + = 0.67). The Feng group [89] prepared a C60 nanorod by a liquid–liquid interfacial precipitation method and used it as an interlayer for Li-S batteries (LSBs) to suppress the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides via chemical adsorption (Fig. 7c). Chamberlain et al. [90] developed unprecedented, all-fullerene-based redox-flow batteries (RFBs) since fullerene derivatives hold excellent solubility in organic solvents and wide potential differences of various oxidation states. The all-fullerene-based RFBs not only exhibited a high open-circuit voltage up to 1.64 V but also avoided the problem of membrane crossover. Therefore, the all-fullerene-based symmetric system showed the highest capacity retention compared with other asymmetric RFB systems. This work provides a unique concept of utilizing fullerene and represents a significant advancement for conventional RFBs. More recently, Allam et al. [91] reported that fullerene C76 showed superior electrocatalytic activity in vanadium-based RFBs. The addition of C76 can significantly promote the reversibility of an electrochemical reaction, indicated by the reduced average peak separation values and charge-transfer resistance. 6 Summaries and outlooks Since the discovery of fullerenes, many studies have been devoted to probing new fullerene structures, exploring special properties, and developing new applications. Research dedicated to the application of fullerenes in rechargeable batteries is relatively scarce at the moment, as summarized in Table 1 , which presents significant opportunities as well as enormous challenges. Some key issues need to be addressed for the wide application of fullerene in the field of batteries in future research. (1) Developing new functions . The new battery systems developed in recent years have undoubtedly opened broad application prospects for fullerenes [92]. Compared with commercialized LIBs, fullerene has more potential in new battery systems, such as LMBs, SIBs, and other metal battery systems. More importantly, new functions can be discovered based on the unique properties of fullerene, such as conductive agents, protective coatings, and electrolyte additives, rather than just being used as electrode materials. Fullerene may not be suitable as the main component in battery systems, due to its high cost [93]. Therefore, how to sophisticatedly exploit the properties of fullerene at an affordable cost is an important issue. (2) Achieving competitive performances. Pursuing high-performance is an important goal for almost all batteries. Unfortunately, most reported batteries using fullerene-based materials display limited performance improvement. Therefore, in future research will require a systematic performance evaluation, including capacity retention, Coulombic efficiency, and rate performance. Developing suitable methods to prepare fullerene-based materials on a large scale is also helpful to its practical application [94]. Finally, detailed performance comparisons between fullerene-based materials and other carbon materials are required to reasonably evaluate their application prospects. (3) Understanding underlying mechanisms. In order to develop novel fullerene-based materials for batteries, the underlying mechanism must be deeply studied, including the charge transfer pathway, storage mechanism, and interfacial effect [95–97]. Advanced characterization methods, especially in-situ observation techniques can be employed for mechanistic investigation, such as high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), scanning tunneling microscope (STM), in-situ Raman spectroscopy, and in-situ ultraviolet (UV) spectroscopy [98]. In particular, due to the crystallinity and solubility of fullerene, many crystal and liquid characterization technologies can be explored, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HR-MS) [99]. On the other hand, theoretical calculations of energy band structures, molecular dynamics, and reaction paths also help reveal the mechanism of fullerene-based materials for battery applications [100]. As a unique allotrope of carbon, fullerene still has many properties waiting to be discovered and has broad application prospects in the field of batteries. We hope that this review can motivate further related research on fullerene-based materials for rechargeable batteries as well as energy storage applications. Mendil, A. Belghachi, Phy. Letters A 383 (2019) 2090−2092. Zhipen g Jiang received his Bachelor’s Degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Anhui University of Science and Technology in 2016. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Prof. Jia Xie at the Huazhong University of Science and Technology. His research interests focus on lithium metal batteries and the application of advanced carbon materials. Yu-ming Zhao is a senior engineer (Professor level) in Shenzhen Power Supply Bureau Co. He received his Ph.D. from Tsinghua University in 2006. His current research focuses on energy storage technology, DC transmission and distribution technology, external insulation of power grid. He has won several China Electric Power Science and Technology Progress Awards and the CSG Science and Technology Progress Awards. Xing Lu is a full professor at Huazhong University of Science and Technology. He received his Ph.D. degree from Peking University in 2004. Then he worked as a COE Postdoctor at Nagoya University. From 2006 to 2011, he was a Senior Scientist at University of Tsukuba. His research interests lie in the rational design and facile generation of novel hybrid carbon materials with applications in energy storage/conversion and biology. Jia Xie received his Ph.D. in the Department of Chemistry from Stanford University. He is now a professor at Huazhong University of Science and Technology. He was a Senior Researcher in Dow Chemical (USA) from 2008-2012 and the CTO of Hefei Guoxuan High-Tech Power Energy Co., Ltd from 2012-2015. His research interests focus on advanced energy storage materials and devices.

coredata.dc:description: The development of high-performance batteries is inseparable from the exploration of new materials. Among them, fullerene C60 as an allotrope of carbon has many unique properties that are beneficial for battery applications, including precise structure, controllable derivatization, good solubility, and rich redox chemistry. In this review, we summarize the recent progress of fullerene-based materials in the field of rechargeable batteries and the key issues that need to be solved in the future application of fullerene. We hope this review can provide guidance and stimulate research about the applications of fullerenes in the field of energy storage.
